newsitem.title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: U.S. envoy reports rights breakthrough with Kabila.
newsitem.headline: U.S. envoy reports rights breakthrough with Kabila.

text.p: U.S. special envoy Bill Richardson held talks with President Laurent Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo on Saturday and reported a breakthrough on the plight of Rwandan Hutu refugees.
Richardson, Washington's ambassador to the United Nations, said Kabila promised a U.N. commission access to investigate allegations of massacres in areas controlled by Kabila's forces.
"This is a major breakthrough ... we have made major progress on the human rights and humanitarian front," Richardson told reporters after the talks in the southern mining capital of Lubumbashi.
He said an advance team would arrive by June 20 and work would start in earnest by July 7.
Richardson was to fly on to Kisangani, where international concern about the plight of Rwandan Hutu refugees has coloured Kabila's takeover.
The refugees are the rump of over a million who fled Rwanda fearing reprisals in 1994 after Hutu hardliners slaughtered hundreds of thousands of minority Tutsis.
Kabila's main allies are Tutsis from Rwanda and the refugees include many civilians but also fighters of Rwanda's former Hutu army who were blamed for the genocide.
The U.N. has airlifted home tens of thousands of Rwandan Hutus, others have fled to neighbouring Congo Brazzaville.
Richardson was heading a team of over a dozen experts from different branches of the U.S. administration, who will brief Kabila's government on international expectations.
"They will be sticking close to the ministers and advising them what the international community wants to see -- but not really telling them what to do," one U.S. official told Reuters.
U.S. officials said that the initiative was unprecedented for Africa and ressembled something Washington organised for Eastern Europe following the collapse of Soviet Communism there.
Richardson and Kabila met at the Lubumbashi offices of the state mining giant Gecamines. "We are here with a broad delegation... we are eager to have a dialogue," Richardson said.
His team included representatives from departments such as defense, treasury, commerce plus aid and human rights experts.

Richardson was at the centre of diplomatic efforts to ensure what he called a "soft landing" when Kabila's forces arrived in Kinshasa, the capital of the former Zaire on May 17, one day after veteran dictator Mobutu Sese Seko fled the city.
Kabila and his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (AFDL) ousted Mobutu after a seven-month civil war. Mobutu had ruled since a 1965 military coup.
Kabila proclaimed himself president with sweeping powers and was inaugurated last month. He has promised elections by April 1999.
Zaire, plundered by Mobutu and his cronies, was potentially one of Africa's richest nations with a wealth of minerals, hydroelectric energy potential and rich farmland.

Kabila and his government have flirted in public with the idea of free market economics but he and his team have a Marxist or socialist past and have spoken in favour of state intervention in key sectors.
Ministers have spoken of making certain mining contracts conditional on implementation of socially important schemes such as road building.
